newsitem.title: USA: Estonia sees tough negotiations to join EU.
newsitem.headline: Estonia sees tough negotiations to join EU.

text.p: Estonia expects to join the European Union within seven to 10 years after tough negotiations, Foreign Minister Toomas Ilves said on Wednesday.
"I think the negotiations will be long and somewhat tough," Ilves told a news briefing in Washington.
But he said rapid EU entry would be unwise for the Baltic state and could prove to be an economic disaster.
The European Commission this month named Estonia and five other Central and Eastern European nations as candidates for membership negotiations. A final decision on the talks is expected in December.
Ilves said joining the EU had been the focus of Estonia's foreign affairs policy in recent months and embassies had been opened in key European capitals.
Estonia also wanted to be among countries chosen to join NATO when the military alliance invites a second round of new members to join, he added.

NATO voted at a summit in Madrid this month to ratify the expansion of NATO to include former Soviet bloc members Hungary, Poland and the Czech Republic. Current members also agreed to keep the door open to future applicants after the first wave is expected to enter in April 1999.
Asked about Russian objections to the Baltic states joining NATO, Ilves said Moscow had no right to interfere in the security arrangements of other nations.
"We do not have to prove ourselves to Russia to join NATO," he said.
Ilves said Russian opposition to Estonia joining NATO was one reason why Estonians wanted membership.
